pullRequest.body:
Defines `L.Expands L'` to consist of a privileged injective inclusion, `L'.Inclusion L`, from `L'` to `L`, corresponding to one language being a subset of the other in set-theoretic foundations.
Replaces `L.IsOrdered` with `L.Expands Language.order` and `L.OrderLHom` with `Language.order.Inclusion L`
Redefines `leSymb` in terms of `Language.order.Inclusion L`

Deletions:
- `FirstOrder.Language.IsOrdered`
- `FirstOrder.Language.OrderLHom`
- `instance : IsOrdered Language.order`
- `sum.instIsOrdered`

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [65b47767bc](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16550/commits/65b47767bcf37e0f8cf08d8ac5f7733076a80b6c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Expands`
`+ Injective.comp`
`+ inclusion`
`+ inclusion_injective`
`+ inclusion_leSymb`
`+ instance : (L''.sum L).Expands L'`
`+ instance : (L.sum L'').Expands L'`
`+ instance : L.Expands L`
`+ instance {α : Type*} : L[[α]].Expands L`
`+ leSymb`
`+ onFunction`
`+ onRelation`
`+ toHom_injective`
`+ trans`
`- IsOrdered`
`- instance : IsOrdered Language.order`
`- orderLHom`
`- orderLHom_leSymb`
`- orderLHom_order`
`- sum.instIsOrdered`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
@ChrisHughes24 , do you think generalizing some of the model theory of rings API to a language with `L.Expands Language.ring` makes sense?
I'm not sure how important it is really for `Expands` to have the injective field, but once I called the map `Inclusion` it felt appropriate.
How much more annoying would it be to work with non-`class` language embeddings instead of this canonical language embedding `class`?

One thing that I definitely want classes for is particular symbols. For instance, I want the language of additive groups, the language of rings, and the language of ordered rings to each have a privileged symbol for addition, such that the type of `Term`s can get an `Add` instance. I think I'd want this for the symbols `0, 1, +, -, x, inv, ≤`.

In order to do this, I think we either need a general solution like this, or several classes along the lines of the current `IsOrdered`. Maybe instead of a class for each symbol, we have a class for each of `AddGroup`, `Monoid`, `Group`, and `LE`.

It may also be helpful to have this kind of thing as a class for translating between model-theoretic and other forms of `HomClass`, but I'm already a bit confused as to the best solution for this sort of thing.

There are two other things that `IsOrdered` is currently used for, which I think we could probably generalize with explicit language map variables:

`IsOrdered` is used as an input to `OrderedStructure`, which is also analogous to `CompatibleRing` - this seems more possible to handle with an embedding that doesn't come from a class. That way, if `ϕ : Language.order →ᴸ L`, maybe we could change `L.OrderedStructure M` to work as `ϕ.OrderedStructure M`, indicating that the image of the symbol for ≤ under `ϕ` is interpreted as it should be in `M`.

`IsOrdered` is also used to define things like `L.preorderTheory`, but we could just define `preorderTheory : Language.order.Theory` and work with `ϕ.onTheory preorderTheory`.

I see. I agree with the first use case (namely have nice notation corresponding to the non-model theory world), and I also agree that the other two use cases (namely `OrderedStructure` and `preorderTheory`) would be better done without `Expanding` the way you suggest in the above message.

@ChrisHughes24, do you have time to provide thoughts here?

```suggestion
abbrev inclusion [L'.Expands L] : L →ᴸ L' := Expands.toLHom
```
Is this not a recipe for diamonds? Should `(L.sum L).Expands L` be the inclusion into the left component, or the right one?

It is. I don't think this will ever actually come up with the kinds of languages that we will actually implement in mathlib, but there are few enough of those that these can both be made `def`s anyway.

pullRequest.title: feat(ModelTheory): A typeclass for languages expanding other languages
